bboxes.raw_text:
WASHINGTON The US. SUI
preme Court was asked to end
a practice used by numerous
southern communities to system
atically exclude Negro citizens
from juries.


Constance Baker Motley, as
sociate counsel of the NAACP
Legal Defense Fund, argued that
the 1862 conviction of Robert
Swain should be reversed.


While few Talladega County
Negroes are included on the jury
rolls, they have been consistently
struck by prosecutors, Mrs.
Motley stressed.


The US. Civil Rights Commits
sion's 1861 report indicates that
this practice Is widely used
across the deep south.


Robert Swain, the defendant,
was sentenced to death for the
alleged rape of a white woman.


The civil rights lawyer pointed
out that no Negro has served on
a trial jury in Talladega County
in either civil or criminal cases.


This was Mrs. Motleys ninth
appearance before the US. Su-
preme Court. Assisting her were
Legal Defense Fund Director
Counsel Jack Greenberg: James
M. Nabrit III. Michael Meltsner
and Frank Heffron of the Fund
New York City headquarters.


Cooperating Attorneys Orzell
Billingsley, Jr. and Peter Hall
of Birmingham assisted on the
case as did volunteer attorney,
Henry M. di Suvero.

SUprem e Court
To Judge Tactics

NEW YORK A Judge dis
missed charges against "a young
parents protesting a contro-
versial "school-pairing' plan in
Queens.


Queens Criminal Court Judge
Morris Weinfeld ruled that the
parents had improperly been
placed under citizens arrest by
the principal Of a school where
they were demonstrating last
Oct. 7.

WASHINGTON The Supreme
Court struck down a Florida
law prohibiting a Negro and a
white person who are not married
to each other from occupying the
same room at night.


However, the court did not act
against the Florida law which
prohibits racial intermarriage.

The same type of law is still
in effect in lo states.


A unanimous opinion read by
Justice Bryan R.White cast doubt
on such laws stating it was an
indication of police powers which
infringed upon individual free
domS.

For the past few years one man has become
the seD-abbOinted great white father for all
minority groups in the Valley. Robert Cho0te
has assumed the monumental task of dire citing
all types of programs which pertain to persons
of the Negro race.


He has managed to get q footh0ld in many
agencies and has been appointed usually by
himself to head community activities. AS the
bYgvious year passes into history, nv. ChO0te
has bombovded the Valley Of the Sun with his
claims of the gigantic Voyk Of his remedies
for dYobouts and career interests. Little has
been proven by any Of his efforts as far as
knoup or evidenced IN the Negro neighbour
hoods.


Choate has ignored existing Negro conferred
groups and Negro leaders in our community.
Instead, he has set himself ON pinnacle and
has rushed about promoting mostly NM: Choote


AS the antiboveYty program is in its infancy,
Cho0te rushed ahead and organized steering
committee to implement some ontiboUeTy
program in the city without the Obvious utili-
zotion of the aid of Negro citizens.


The re cent Urban League Equal ObboYt1Ga-
ity Day turned into a tiasco. Choate used
seemingly as a stepping stone for another
one of his self Qualification programs.


It is still true that man WbO wears too
naaey hats, usually has no time to Oeor any
too weu Apparently, Robert Choate fails into
the category characterized by Negro leader
uho said, HE uses race relations as some
kind of hobby"


Choate and others, WhetheY they are C0u-
cosion or Negro, should realize that Negroes
are not a GROUP of illiteyutes waiting IKE
bunch of cattle to be led from place to place.

James A. Horton right who last week editor
of Agricultural Marketing publication of the US. Department
of Agriculture shown studying issue of the monthly
with Administrator S. R. Smith of USDs Agricultural Marketing
Service Mr. Horton had assistant editor of the publication
for years. USDA Photo

birthday party given by members of the Order Of the
Eastern Star Marcopa Chapter honorng members of the Palm
Chapter.


Mrs. Virginia Curry northy of the OES Chapter
Prince affiliate, welcomed than hundred honorees
and guests the affair.
Mrs. Vernela president of the Palm Chapter.


Pr Bobby Heard
